titleStmt.title: Letter, Andrew Jackson Donelson in Washington, to his wife, Elizabeth Jan. 18, 1857

publicationStmt.publisher: The University of Tennessee Libraries Digital Initiatives

availability.p: The copyright interests in this collection remain with the creator. For more information, contact the Special Collections Library.

bibl.title: Letter, Andrew Jackson Donelson in Washington, to his wife, Elizabeth Jan. 18, 1857

projectDesc.p: Machine-readable transcription created for the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections.

editorialDecl.p: Errors in transcription of the printed text not controlled.
Editorial tags limited to gap and unclear.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

revisionDesc.change: Approximate date of original transcription and transcriber.
Migrating from P4 to validated TEI P5.

div.p: It is eleven at night and your letter of the co. reaches me just in time to answer it before the hafu goes to press. Tomorrow is Landay the only biseue I have for the answer of a thousand whilual letters. I will devote it to my private affairs and will give an hour to Mr. Alexander, who I am valifull from your letter ought not to be again employed. Do the best you can with him until the year is out

What you say of Mary greives me moress. I would as soon see a Rupean brar about her as the Dr you mention. Lecture her kindly. I hope Rachel is doing better. You know if I could have avoided it I would not be here. It was cimpopible to make the money necessary to out wants & family. Something was to be done and I hoped that you could manage without me for a little while. I am doing my duty, but am full of trouble, assailed by bent for more than by open enemies. Wait but a little longer and we shall see whether I was right or wrong.
Kiss all the children. I will write again tomorrow. V. aff. Husband
